results.title: BMX is life
results.creator_credit: Harley Van Belkolm, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Riding and doing tricks on his BMX is when Harley Van Belkolm feels free. He provides some insight into this passion of his, the culture that surrounds it and why he wouldn’t be doing anything else.

results.title: Times have changed
results.creator_credit: Lillian Murray, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Lillian Murray has worked in the offices of Legacy in Melbourne’s CBD for the last 29 years. It is her home away from home and she reflects on the technological changes there as well as the good times and the great people she has the pleasure to work with.

results.title: Realisation
results.creator_credit: Scott Percival, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Scott Percival thought he and his friends from Legacy were going to Perth for a little R&R. While he didn’t get the rest he’d hoped for, he got more than he could have imagined.

results.title: 1946 : my first year nursing
results.creator_credit: Jean Cussen, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Jean Cussen’s father returned from the war, she took up nursing at the Children’s Hospital in Carlton. She provides, in rich detail, her time there, the children she cared for and how caring for these poor children brought the staff so much pleasure.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jean Cussen, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Passing the baton on
results.creator_credit: Margot Firth-Smith, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: While Margot Firth-Smith’s beloved father returned from the war, he came back a very old man and died soon after. To fill the gap, Firth-Smith joined Legacy which set her off on a rewarding life helping others.

results.title: Spectacle Talks: Gotye and his Collaborators
results.creator_credit: Gotye, Mike Kenneally, Kim Montgomery, Shelley Matulick and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Multi award-winning musician, songwriter and producer Gotye is no stranger to collaboration. His music videos are a testament to this, utilising the talents of diverse directors, artists and animators. Often involving a range of complex animation and filmmaking techniques, visual worlds are created floating seamlessly against his music.
Natasha Pincus, Andrew Goldsmith, and directors of Rubber House animation studio Ivan Dixon and Greg Sharp disscus a selection of Gotye’s most renowned videos. These include ‘Easy Way Out’, ‘Seven Hours With A Back Seat Driver’, ‘State Of The Art’ and the international chart-topping ‘Somebody That I Used To Know’.
Hosted by film and music critic Megan Spencer, this event provided a fascinating insight into the collaborative journey, from initial concept and creative development, through to final clip production.

results.title: A Dose of reality
results.creator_credit: Andrew Dobbyn, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Andrew Dobbyn feels he has lived a privileged life. A baby boomer with a war veteran father, Dobbyn’s family did what they could to help the wives and children of those who didn’t return from the war. Despite this, Dobbyn felt he could be doing more and highlights two events in his life that showed him just how lucky he is.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Andrew Dobbyn, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: On a Sunday he went fishing
results.creator_credit: Sarah Mifsud, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

video_links.name: On a Sunday he went fishing

results.brief_description: Sarah Mifsud’s father was an avid fisherman as was his father before him. Mifsud tells of the ordinary Sunday which turned tragically extraordinary for her family and the journey to rebuild in the aftermath.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sarah Mifsud, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: An Interview with Gillian Armstrong
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Shelley Matulick and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Award-winning Australian film and documentary director Gillian Armstrong’s film career spans over 40 years locally and internationally.

Here she shares her discovery of Orry-Kelly and the incredibly fortunate set of events that uncovered his memoir and his box of memorabilia including his three Oscars.

The release of Armstrong’s 2015 feature-length documentary on the life and work of renowned costume designer Orry-Kelly, ‘Women He’s Undressed’, coincided with ACMI’s exhibition ‘Orry-Kelly: Dressing Hollywood’.
